item.title: Theory: Nash Equilibrium
item.description: [WARNING] Citeproc: citation Nash1951 not found So far, we have looked at two solution concepts: (i) rationalizable strategies, which donâ€™t exist for all games, and (ii) optimal or minimax strategies for zero-sum games. Now, we look at the most popular solution concept in games, known as Nash Equilibrium. Definition A Nash equilibrium (in pure strategies) of a strategic game \(\mathscr{G} = \langle \ALPHABET N, (\ALPHABET A_i)_{i \in \ALPHABET N}, (u_i)_{i \in \ALPHABET N} \rangle\) is a strategy profile \(a^* = (a^*_1, \dots, a^*_n) \in \ALPHABET A\) such that for each player \(i \in \ALPHABET N\), and each strategy \(a_i \in \ALPHABET A_i\), we have \[ u_i(a_i^*, a_{-i}^*) \ge u_i(a_i, a_{-i}^*).
